14211111211212211.content:
"We're going to phib our way out of this," Aaron replied. "We just got to play it cool. I'm going to sneak back in first - get out the hero getup for a second. Turn off the lights at the front porch." Running with quiet steps, Aaron then rounded the house and came in through the dim front entrance.

Entering the house, Hank met him in the living room, looking uncertain. "So what are you going to tell them?" he asked, "be careful - I'd rather not have to deal with the police."

Throwing off the hero outfit, Aaron began to explain his plan to Hank as the two of them walked upstairs, where Aaron changed into a pair of loose jeans and normal black t-shirt. "It's easy," Aaron explained, "they seem to think we're murderers or human traffickers or something, and I think they based that off the fact that we have a prisoner." Aaron gestured towards his current body to indicate who he meant, "but they only saw the room at its most empty - with the cells and cameras. They don't know about any of the weapons or tools or none of that. So if I go out there as Ariana, I might be able to convince them nothing dangerous is going on, which will make them think they don't have any dirt. We can just claim its... a party floor!"

"But how do we brush off the cells?" Hank asked. "I don't go to a lot of parties, but most of them don't have prison cells."

"I'll figure that out as I go along," Aaron replied as he looked around for shoes. Unfortunately they only had the combat boots that he wore for the costume. He instead settled for a pair of flip flops. "So long as I play it casual, I think we'll be in the clear."

Satisfied with his appearance, Aaron proceeded to head back downstairs, and exited into the backyard, approaching the three figures. "Hey, what's up? My friend says you're bugging him," he called out in the woman's voice, "what's the damage, he paid you guys right?"

The black man kept his cool, but his two lackeys seemed a bit nervous at the sight of the woman. "Yo boss, she seems fine," he said, trying but failing to whisper. "Maybe we had the wrong impression?"

"Shut up man; they haven't killed her but that probably just means she's in on it. They have cages for crying out loud."

"Hey, can you speak to me?" Aaron called out, putting a hand to one hip and pointing to his chest. "I'm asking you all a question."

"We want more cash if you want us to keep quiet!" the leader asserted. "We know you all are up to no good down there. Why all hush hush?"

Aaron flicked his hair, trying to act nonchalant. "It's their party pad," he explained, "they're just rich teens who want to make their club. Don't you think you're over blowing this?"

"You're full of shit. The prison cells? What kind of party has cells," he replied, trying to make eye contact through the gloom. Aaron admitted, he was at a disadvantage here. He was lit by the lights that lined the walls of the house - they could see all his expression - if he made a single tell then the ruse might shatter. They had the dark on their side, he couldn't see how close they were to faltering.

Keeping his cool, he proceeded on. "People get drunk and high at parties, dumbass," he replied, shooting right back with the aggression. "Ever hear of a 'drunk tank'? They have those there so that anyone who passes out or can't head home has a place to lie down."

"Why the locks?"

"Because otherwise they'd just go back into the party, fuckface. It's like you aren't even thinking. Now, do you want me to call the cops and tell them my friend is being falsely extorted and blackmailed by three thugs?" He still couldn't see their faces, but he could bet they were backing down now. This body gave him all the confidence he needed to stare assholes like these down; he knew he could take as Arianna, so he didn't hold back on the insults.

After a moment of silence, the leader of the three finally gave an answer.

Aaron immediately rushes to the book and starts rummaging through the pages, hoping to find who's name Ramsey wrote down. About five or six pages in, Aaron froze in terror as he noticed who's name was written down. It was his. Aaron was about to start panicking when he felt a weird tingling sensation on the back of his neck. This sensation quickly spread down his back and across his limbs. Aaron dropped the notebook onto the floor as he was slowly beginning to lose feeling of his arms and legs. He fell onto his knees, feeling too stiff to move.

"You shouldn't have tried to double-cross me like that Aaron. Don't you know that your actions have consequences?" Aaron could hear Ramsey speaking to him, but he couldn't see where he was. It didn't take him long to realise that Ramsey was speaking to him inside his head.

"Look, I'm sorry okay." Aaron said, pain in his voice. "I shouldn't have tried burning the notebook, it was a stupid thing to do, just please, don't possess me." Aaron's vision was starting to lose focus. The sensation was starting to numb and he started feeling tired. It felt as if he could fall sleep right then and there. Aaron tried his best not to fall asleep.

"Even if you possess me, people will know something is off about me. You won't win this in the end." Aaron replied, his voice getting weaker. He lips were feeling numb, making talking a lot harder than usual.

"I doubt that. I will have access to your memories." Said Ramsey, with amusement. "I will know everything there is to know about you. Besides, I don't want to fit in. I want to have fun. Give in. It'll all be over if you just let me in."

Aaron felt a weight press down on him which made him put his arms in front of him, as if he was kneeling. "Let me in Aaron. Let me in. Let me in." In a way, it felt like a relief. All the weight had been lifted. In fact, it was as if he didn't have any weight at all. He couldn't hear anything, or feel the horrible feelings he experienced before. He could see only darkness, which to him, was peaceful more than it was worrying. This did not last. He noticed his body was still in the same position as it was before, not moving a muscle. He flew towards it, hoping to get back inside, but was pushed away when making contact. He flew in front of his body to see his face. He noticed he was breathing, but his eyes were closed. "Hello?" Aaron said to his body, immediately thinking to himself why he said that.

Not long after, Aaron's body opened his eyes, which made Aaron jump at bit. Aaron's body stood up slowly, looking down at the rest of his body. A small but sinister smile on his face.

"Finally," Ramsey said, with Aaron's voice, "Took him long enough."

I'm 18 years old and I recently graduated high school." Ramsey said to himself, as if he was reading a diary.

Ramsey turned around to face the room. "Hey Aaron, you here? Thanks for trying to burn the notebook. It seems it's ended up pretty well for me." He continued to feel across his body, in a way that was likely supposed to annoy Aaron. At this point, Aaron had lost all the care in the world.
